cards.title: Why Thinking Less About the Future Sometimes Helps

content: A weekly summary of the most beautiful, interesting, and powerful things found on the Internet
Reflections on anxiety and time management inspired by Oliver Burkeman's book 'Four Thousand Weeks'
Strategies to overcome present anxiety by accepting one's own finitude

☑️ ff.44.1 The Modern Fallacy of Time Containers
In his book 'Four Thousand Weeks,' Oliver Burkeman explores how our perception of time has evolved, negatively impacting our productivity and daily task management.

♾️ ff.44.2 Infinity Out There
The digital world offers a constant flow of alternatives, increasing decision-making anxiety and making it difficult to dedicate oneself to a single experience or activity.

🏠 ff.44.3 Settling Stabilizes
According to Heidegger, definitive commitment is essential for existence. Burkeman connects this philosophy to the modern difficulty in making permanent decisions.

🖼️ ff.44.4 Wasting 3 Hours in Front of a Painting
Jennifer Roberts assigns Harvard students to contemplate a piece of art for 3 hours, demonstrating how mindfulness can reduce anxiety and improve present-focused concentration.

4️⃣ ff.44.5 4 Ways to Find a Cure
Burkeman suggests atelic activities, setting reasonable goals, keeping a done-list, and avoiding forcing carpe diem as strategies to improve mental well-being.

cards.title: An Alternative to the '9-5' Office Job, The Pathless Path

content: Work has never been so central to human life
Why repeating what our parents did doesn't make sense
From McKinsey New York to freedom in Taiwan: Paul Miller, 32 years old

🔥 ff.62.1 Work Has Never Been So Important
The pandemic disrupted traditional work habits, leading only 40% of Americans to maintain jobs that exceed 35 hours per week, highlighting a shift in the work paradigm according to Burkeman.

🥾 ff.62.2 Stepping Off the Main Path
Paul Miller leaves a promising career at 32 to pursue a more authentic life, demonstrating that many freelancers find greater personal satisfaction by embracing unconventional paths.

🧾 ff.62.3 Taxing Misery
Bevan's 'misery tax' concept highlights how unhappy workers lose productivity, while Ben-Shahar introduces the arrival fallacy as a main cause of work dissatisfaction.

🔺 ff.62.4 The Pyramid Within Us All
Maslow's hierarchy of needs is unmet in 60% of modern workers, leading to existential crises according to Lieberman.

🕹️ ff.62.5 Independence and Curiosity
Remote working has increased job satisfaction, while Miller's creativity suggestions reduce burnout, promoting a more balanced work environment.

cards.title: The Modern Individual Between Speedy Songs, Calorie Tracking, and Species Evolution

content: More and more fast and monitored
My first marathon and the anxiety of losing the achieved form
The cure proposed by Naval

🏃🏻 ff.68.1 More and More Fast
The acceptable time for loading a web page decreased from 4 to 2 seconds in three years, increasing our impatience and anxiety.

📏 ff.68.2 More and More Measured and Controlled
We measure everything: from sleep to calories, with an increase in the use of tracking apps leading to a rise in mental anxiety.

☝️ ff.68.3 There Is No Limit to the Best (or the Worst?)
Only a small percentage of marathoners manage to finish under 3 hours, but social pressure increases ego and the anxiety to continuously improve.

🎁 ff.68.4 Less Ego and Control, More Flow and Present: Naval's Cure
Naval Ravikant proposes 'groundedness,' which through acceptance exercises and present-focused practices, reduces anxious activity according to neuroscientific studies.

cards.title: Focusing on One Thing to Combat Generative Art and Continuous Distractions

content: Doing one thing at a time
Listening to a heartbreaking CD
How classics and the Greeks relate to the content invasion

♾️ ff.72.1 Digital Infinity
Our digital society offers over 100 daily alternatives, increasing decision-making anxiety and making it difficult to focus on a single activity.

💿 ff.72.2 Listening to a CD
Only a minority of Spotify users listen to an entire album without distractions, highlighting a decrease in musical concentration compared to the past.

📚 ff.72.3 If the Library of Alexandria Had 100 Books
Naval Ravikant suggests that thoroughly reading 100 books can improve comprehension and reduce multitasking anxiety.

🇬🇷 ff.72.4 From Multitasking to Greek Classics (and Arete)
The Greek arete philosophy improves productivity and the quality of relationships compared to modern multitasking, according to recent studies.
Using Artificial Intelligence to predict protein structures and innovative drugs
Resurrecting mammoths and the crossword puzzle
Applications of AI in chemistry and biology

🧬 ff.4.1 Protein Structure
About a year ago, DeepMind demonstrated the ability to determine protein structures within hours. It took 50 years to understand how to do this.

💊 ff.4.2 The Next Innovative Drug
An Artificial Intelligence was trained to predict the properties of chemical structures, reducing the time from 3 months to 3 hours.

🦖 ff.4.3 Resurrected Mammoths from Extinction
Colossal is attempting to resurrect mammoths to rebalance the tundra ecosystem and improve genetic editing techniques.

📉 ff.4.4 DNA Better than Microchips!
The cost of sequencing the human genome has decreased by 100,000 times in the last 20 years, making it cheaper than the latest iPhone.

🦠 ff.4.5 Computational Microbes?
Researchers have created mazes solvable by E. coli, demonstrating computational capabilities based on biological substrates.

cards.title: 🦠 COVID and Deaths in the United States

content: The New York Times Pixels
Infinite Scroll Accumulating Deaths
The Washington Post's Interrupted Sentences

⚈ ff.27.1 The New York Times Pixels
The New York Times visualized one million COVID deaths in the United States using pixels, where each dot represents a human life. This approach makes it challenging to dedicate time to each individual dot but encourages reflection on the pandemic's scale.

🖱️ ff.27.2 Scroll and Deaths
Axios created an interactive visualization that accumulates deaths as the page is scrolled. By January 2021, the death toll matched that of World War II in the United States. By September 2021, it surpassed the 1918 pandemic victims, approaching one million deaths.

💬 ff.27.3 The Washington Post's Interrupted Sentences
The Washington Post presented interrupted sentences to represent individual COVID-19 victims' stories. This method requires the reader to pause and reflect, highlighting the brain's difficulty in handling interruptions and anticipations.

cards.title: 🔍 Google and Artificial Intelligence for the Future

content: Controlling 'the sun on earth'
Counting beans and assessing crop efficiency
Reducing emissions in Google Maps travels
Analyzing our health data

☢️ ff.28.1 Artificial Intelligence for Nuclear Fusion
Nuclear fusion has been predicted for decades, as discussed in 🎼 ff.12 Sun, heart, and love. Recently, Nature published the use of neural networks to control the position and shape of plasma in a nuclear fusion reactor. AI, through Deep Reinforcement Learning, managed the system faster than traditional physics calculations, allowing the creation of various plasma configurations, including the 'snowflake,' essential for optimizing energy generation.

🧆 ff.28.2 Finding Bazar's Bean
Project Mineral by X, a Google-connected startup, utilizes robotics, image recognition, and biology to enhance agriculture. With over 30,000 known edible plant species, only 1% are cultivated by humans. Project Mineral aims to bridge this knowledge gap, promoting biodiversity and improving crop efficiency through the analysis and mapping of new varieties.

🗺️ ff.28.3 Google Maps Reduces Emissions
Google has implemented an eco-friendly driving system on Maps, avoiding traffic jams and reducing engine-on time, thereby contributing to lower emissions. Recently, options for bicycles and e-scooters were added, along with electric vehicle charging stations. Google estimates that these features can prevent the emission of 1 million tons of CO2 annually, equivalent to the emissions of 200,000 cars.

🩺 ff.28.4 Put on a Tank Top (or Feel Lucky?)
Google launched Care Studio, a health data management platform that provides doctors with patient data in an easy-to-access, AI-assisted manner. Additionally, Nest Hub 2, Google’s smart home mini-tablet, can monitor sleep-wake cycles with 3D radar and assist disabled individuals in communication, enhancing their daily well-being.

publications.buttonLabel: 🎼 ff.76 Are We Still in Lockdown?
publications.title: 🎼 ff.76 Are We Still in Lockdown?

content: Has it turned us into Kafka's cockroach?
Remote work, yoga, bicycles: which trends have survived?
Is playing Minecraft harder after COVID?

🦠 ff.76.1 What Remains of COVID?
COVID has largely become a distant memory. I view the lockdown period like my 2 years in the Netherlands: a sealed and isolated compartment of life where I became a completely different person. The 65 million people affected by long COVID in Europe highlight the psycho-physical scars left by the pandemic, including symptoms like shortness of breath, concentration deficits, and insomnia.

🧖‍♂️ ff.76.2 The Explosion of Hobbies
During the lockdown, 1 in 2 Americans started a new hobby, leading to a resurgence of home-based interests such as DIY projects, yoga, and cycling. This explosion of hobbies reflects a desire for connection and personal improvement during times of isolation.

🫁 ff.76.3 And the Physical Effects
The lockdown has left significant physical marks, with 65 million people in Europe suffering from long COVID. Games like Minecraft now include modes that simulate chronic symptoms, highlighting the lasting impact of the pandemic on daily life and mental health.

🐛 ff.76.4 Transformed into a Cockroach?
Bruno Latour proposes a philosophy of lockdown, likening the human experience to Kafka's cockroach. The lockdown confirmed our materiality, prompting us to reflect on our physical existence and the limitations imposed by the pandemic.

publications.title: 🎼 ff.87 We are what we breathe

cards.title: 🫁 Breathing between anxiety, polluted air, and air purifiers

content: Do processed foods make us snore?
The social cost of pollution
Should we buy air purifiers for citizens?

💨 ff.87.1 A brief history of breathing
Feuerbach argued that we are what we eat. Over the past two centuries, processed foods have changed the shape of our palate, causing issues like snoring, linked to the use of bottles versus natural breastfeeding.

🏭 ff.87.2 How polluted is Italy's air?
In the Po Valley, air quality resembles Mordor, with critical NO2 emissions. Recent data show a slight decrease in PM2.5 concentrations in Milan. Air Quality Index 450 equals smoking 30 cigarettes a day; living in Milan is like smoking two cigarettes a day.

🔄 ff.87.3 An air purifier for everyone
The cost of an air purifier to increase an American's life expectancy by 1 DALY is estimated at $33k, while in India it's $1.5k. A European can offset 20 years of emissions with €65k by installing a wind turbine.

💆🏻‍♀️ ff.87.4 Breathing against stress: the 3-4-5 method
The 3-4-5 technique involves inhaling for 3 seconds, holding for 4 seconds, and exhaling for 5, and it is helpful for reducing stress.

cards.title: 🧘‍♂️ Notifications and social media: this jungle is destroying me

content: Do social media trigger a response like a lion in the savannah?
Cortisol, diet, notifications, and sports
Stress and diabetes, what’s the connection?

🦁 ff.90.1 Running from a lion or a notification
Notifications trigger a physiological response similar to our evolutionary fight-or-flight mechanism, raising glucose and cortisol levels to prepare for running. However, we remain seated, leading to non-dietary glucose spikes that contribute to obesity and diabetes.

😵‍ ff.90.2 Microdoses of stress
In 'The Stress Solution', Dr. Rangan Chatterjee discusses how microdoses of stress (notifications, emails at night) accumulate throughout the day, eventually leading to obesity and insomnia.

🥽 ff.90.3 Microbiomes under stress
Stress disrupts the gut microbiome by reducing beneficial microbes like Lactobacillus while promoting harmful ones like Citrobacter, negatively affecting metabolic health.

🏓 ff.90.4 Sports against stress
Physical activity, even just walking 2 minutes after 20 minutes of sitting, counters excessive glucose and cortisol levels. Though it’s stressful, exercise helps the body manage chronic stress more effectively.

publications.title: 🎼 ff.17 Sports (and who makes poop out of it)

cards.title: 💩 Strava and the bathroom data to break the next world record

content: Can urine and feces tell us if we will break a world record?
Are we a species of walkers?
Do we train more when seeing our friends' activities on Strava?

🇳🇴 ff.17.1 Norway is obsessed
Kristian Blummenfelt, a Norwegian triathlete, broke impressive records in triathlon and Ironman, even while facing weather challenges and taking bathroom breaks. Engineer Olav Aleksander Bu analyzed his feces and urine to optimize carbohydrate and oxygen consumption, improving his performance.

🏃 ff.17.2 Strava's 2021 report
Strava saw a 38% increase in activities compared to 2020, with walking showing the most growth. Those who started in 2020 saw significant personal best improvements in 2021.

🕸️ ff.17.3 Positive social networks?
MIT's Sinan Aral studied social influence on Strava, showing that seeing a friend run 1 km more pushes us to run at least 750 meters extra, with even weather patterns in distant locations affecting this behavior.

publications.buttonLabel: 🎼 ff.22 Do we eat too much?
publications.title: 🎼 ff.22 Do we eat too much?

cards.title: ⚖️ Circadian rhythms, calories, and mice that don't gain weight

content: Can we eat anything if we do it within a 10-hour window?
Do we eat more when in company?
Is there really a diet with just one meal a day?

🕐 ff.22.1 Circadian diet?
The book 'Circadian Code' emphasizes the importance of biological rhythms for mental and physical well-being. Eating within a 10-12 hour window helps regulate our metabolism. A study in Nature Metabolism shows that mice consuming the same daily calories lose more weight when food is limited to a shorter time frame.

🪑 ff.22.2 Add a seat (and some calories) at the table
Being in company can make us eat up to 50% more than when we're alone.

🥔 ff.22.3 Why eat unprocessed (and fiber-rich) foods
Unprocessed food requires more energy to digest. For example, digesting a sandwich with whole-grain bread uses twice as many calories as one with white bread.

🤰🏻 ff.22.4 The most filling foods
Potatoes top the list of most satiating foods with a satiety index of 332, while croissants rank at 47. Oranges and apples are more filling than bananas.

🍹 ff.22.5 Drinking it away?
Alcohol consumption can add up: 5 beers a week can lead to an additional 5.6 kg in a year.
